item.title: US, Chinese Trade Negotiators Meet as APEC Slashes Growth View
item.description: US and Chinese trade negotiators met again for talks just days after a key truce on tariffs as officials from the world’s biggest economies gathered in South Korea to assess the weakened state of global commerce.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Yoshiaki Nohara, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer. Photographer: Drew Angerer/Getty Images

item.title: Irish Exports to US Soar 395% in March on Tariff Threat
item.description: The value of exports from Ireland to the US rose 394.9% in March from a year earlier, on medical and pharmaceutical goods, the statistics office said.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: Sample bottles at the production lab in the Eli Lilly & Co. manufacturing plant in Kinsale, Ireland.

item.title: JPMorgan’s Global Markets Head Says US Could Dodge a Recession
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co.’s chief of global markets strategy said the US could dodge a recession as the probability of that scenario has decreased following better clarity over global trade.
item.dc:creator: Meg Short

item.title: Meloni Wants Another Cut to Italy’s Payroll Taxes in Next Budget
item.description: Italian Premier Giorgia Meloni’s government wants to ease the burden on middle-class earnings with another giveaway in the coming year, according to the economics chief of her political party.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio, Donato Paolo Mancini

item.title: Banxico Is Expected to Deliver Half-Point Rate Cut
item.description: Mexico will likely maintain the pace of monetary policy easing Thursday, offering up a half-point rate cut as the economy shows signs of prolonged weakness with inflation inside the target range.
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch, Alex Vasquez

item.title: Euro Zone Grew Less Than Initially Reported at Start of Year
item.description: The euro-area economy expanded less than initially reported at the start of 2025, even before US tariffs that are expected to sap activity in the months ahead.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

item.title: Trump Says US and Iran Are Closer to Reaching a Nuclear Deal
item.description: President Donald Trump said the US might be getting closer to an agreement with Iran to curb the Islamic Republic’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Sykes

media:content.media:description: (Photo by IIPA via Getty Images) Photographer: Handout/Getty Images Europe

item.title: Trade Chiefs Jostle for Time With Greer at APEC Meeting in Korea
item.description: Trade chiefs from some of the world’s biggest economies are competing for access to US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer as they seek to advance negotiations with Washington at a gathering in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Jamieson Greer Photographer: Kayla Bartkowski/Getty Images

item.title: Romanian Election Brings Junk-Level Risks for Bond Investors
item.description: Investors are treating Romania’s eurobonds on par with junk-rated debt after months of political turmoil, and now the weekend’s presidential ballot brings fresh risks for the currency and local debt as well.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca, Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Campaign posters for presidential candidates in Bucharest. Photographer: Andrei Pungovschi/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Elderson Warns Against Scaling Back ESG Rules Too Much
item.description: European Central Bank Executive Board member Frank Elderson warned against excessively reducing the ESG reporting and regulatory burden on European companies.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

item.title: Swiss GDP Jumped Most in Two Years Before Trump Imposed Tariffs
item.description: Switzerland enjoyed its strongest growth spurt in two years at the start of 2025, unexpectedly accelerating before an anticipated hit from US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: The Zurich HB rail station beyond a busy retail street in Zurich. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Economy Has Best Quarter in a Year With 0.7% Expansion
item.description: The UK economy enjoyed its strongest quarterly growth in a year before the double blow of tax hikes and Donald Trump’s trade war.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Shoppers on Oxford Street, London's busiest shopping destination, in London, UK, on Wednesday, April 23, 2025. UK government borrowing exceeded official forecasts made just last month, highlighting the fragile state of the public finances even before US tariffs dimmed the economic outlook.

item.title: Norway’s Economy Rebounds to Biggest Gain in Almost Three Years
item.description: Norway’s economy surprised with better-than-expected growth in the first quarter, expanding at the fastest pace in almost three years, vindicating the central bank’s cautious stance on easing.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas

media:content.media:description: A battery recycling facility in Fredrikstad, Norway. Photographer: Naina Helén Jåma/Bloomberg

item.title: US Treasuries, Re-Imported Japanese Cars Seen as Trade Leverage
item.description: Holding longer-term Treasuries and importing Japanese cars manufactured in the US are among the possible bargaining chips for Tokyo in its talks with Washington over President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs, according to the leader of a small but influential opposition party.
item.dc:creator: Akemi Terukina, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Traffic travels along a road as pedestrians using umbrellas walk along sidewalks in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, April 1, 2020. Japan’s coronavirus numbers have been ticking up, sparking alarm that it could be the next major country to see an explosive jump in infections. It’s also raising questions about whether Tokyo is about to go into a European-style lockdown -- speculation the government is trying to squash. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

item.title: RBI Seeks to Revive Funding Market Vital for Monetary Policy
item.description: A dwindling borrowing market used mainly by Indian banks is showing signs of life as authorities champion its usage to lenders, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Subhadip Sircar, Bhaskar Dutta

item.title: Bank of Uganda Buys $1.5 Billion, Uses FX Swaps to Grow Reserves
item.description: The Bank of Uganda has bought $1.5 billion from the market this fiscal year and used currency swaps to rebuild its foreign-exchange reserves after they were drained by an aid freeze and debt repayments.
item.dc:creator: Fred Ojambo, Jennifer Zabasajja

item.title: US-China Trade Clash Risks Making Europe Dumping Ground for Cheap Goods
item.description: China’s widening trade surplus with the European Union is fueling fresh concerns that the 27-nation bloc risks becoming a dumping ground for cheap goods in the volatile tariff confrontation between Washington and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Port of Barcelona.

item.title: China’s Glut of Coal Locks Market in Vicious Cycle of Decline
item.description: Chinese coal prices remain locked in a downward spiral due to a persistent glut of the fuel, according to the country’s top industry group.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Kathy Chen

item.title: China Pauses Dual-Use Export Curbs Targeting US Firms
item.description: China has suspended a ban on exports of items with both military and civil applications — likely including some rare earths — to 28 US companies as part of the trade detente struck between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Li Liu

item.title: What’s Going Wrong at Some Of Australia’s Biggest Banks?
item.description: On this week’s Australia Podcast: As the regulator launches yet another probe into bank trading, what is going wrong at some of our biggest financial institutions?

media:content.media:description: A reflection of the Macquarie Group Ltd. logo on the 1 Elizabeth building, which will house the company's headquarters, in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday, May 1, 2024. Macquarie Group is scheduled to report its half-year earnings results on May 3.

item.title: Australia’s Jobs Soar in April, Currency Gains Ahead of RBA
item.description: Australian employment soared in April while the jobless rate held steady as more people sought work, highlighting the resilience of the labor market at a time when the Reserve Bank is expected to reduce interest rates further.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: China’s Investors Signal Trade Truce Is No Panacea for Markets
item.description: The trade truce is not enough to ignite a rush into Chinese financial assets amid expectations of reduced policy stimulus and lingering uncertainty on a final deal.
item.dc:creator: John Cheng, Iris Ouyang

item.title: Foreign Investment in Europe Tumbled Even Before US Trade War
item.description: A measure of foreign direct investment in Europe sank to a nine-year low in 2024, underscoring the continent’s struggle to lure business even before US President Donald Trump’s trade war darkened the economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

item.title: Steve Cohen Says Probability of US Recession Now Stands at 45%
item.description: Billionaire Steve Cohen said the chance of a recession in the US now stands at about 45%.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Burton

item.title: Fed’s Daly Says US Economy Still Solid, Officials Can Be Patient
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said the strength of the US economy allows policymakers to be patient as they wait for more evidence of how the Trump administration’s policies will affect businesses and households.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly.

item.title: Why Trade Deals and Tax Cuts May Be a Recipe for US Success
item.description: On this week’s Trumponomics, Stephen Moore of the Heritage Foundation argues that Donald Trump and the GOP Congress are on the right path.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: Stephen Moore, visiting fellow at the Heritage Foundation, listens during a discussion at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in National Harbor, Maryland, U.S., on Friday, Feb. 28, 2020. President Trump will address this years CPAC after seeking to close ranks within his administration about the threat posed by the coronavirus and how the U.S. government plans to stop its spread following mixed messages that rattled Wall Street.

item.title: Peru’s Endless Political Churn Is Spreading to the Finance Minister Post
item.description: Peru’s messy cabinet reshuffle is spotlighting how political instability is spreading to what was once a treasured post: the finance minister.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun, Maria Elena Vizcaino

media:content.media:description: Dina Boluarte Photographer: Carlos Garcia Granthon/Fotoholica Press/LightRocket/Getty Images

item.title: UK Mulls New Investor Visa Targeting Key Strategic Industries
item.description: The UK is drawing up plans for a special visa for foreigners who invest significant sums in Britain, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s government seeks to blunt the economic blow from recent tax hikes and wider curbs on work permits.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Alex Wickham

item.title: Carney Delays Canada Budget, Plans to Cut Income Tax by July
item.description: Canada will cut the lowest personal income tax rate to 14% from 15% on July 1, but Prime Minister Mark Carney’s new government won’t release a budget before the summer months.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney during a news conference with cabinet members after a swearing-in ceremony at Rideau Hall in Ottawa, Ontario, on May 13.

item.title: US May Need a Bond-Market Blowup to Cut Deficit, Market Veteran Says
item.description: After the November election, there were few people in the bond market more optimistic about how President Donald Trump, and his band of DOGE cost-cutters, would rein in ballooning budget deficits than Stephen Jen.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick
